thread.title: Yankees lose, 9-4, to Orioles, but gain home field - Sports
thread.title_full: Yankees lose, 9-4, to Orioles, but gain home field - Sports - NorthJersey.com

author: PETE CALDERA
title: Yankees lose, 9-4, to Orioles, but gain home field - Sports
text:
Buy this photo ASSOCIATED PRESS Yankees starting pitcher Michael Pineda looks to the bullpen after the Baltimore Orioles scored a run in the fourth inning in Baltimore. BALTIMORE – About the time the Yankees mounted a too-late seventh-inning rally at Camden Yards, the out-of-town scoreboard flashed some good news for Joe Girardi’s embattled club.
At Arizona, Diamondbacks slugger Paul Goldschmidt belted a go-ahead, two-run homer against the Astros.
Needing either a win or an Astros loss to earn the home field for Tuesday’s wild-card game, the Yankees – 9-4 losers Sunday against the Orioles – gladly accepted the Diamondbacks' gift on the final day of the regular season.
Arizona’s 5-3 victory over Houston gave the Yankees what they couldn’t do for themselves.
The Yankees will host the Astros in Tuesday’s one-game wild-card playoff to determine which club will advance to the Division Series against the defending AL champion Kansas City Royals.
But the Yankees (87-75) stumble into the tournament, having dropped six of their last seven games against the Red Sox and Orioles.
Yankees starter Michael Pineda (12-10) lasted just 3.2 innings, charged with four earned runs, while Orioles right-hander Chris Tillman (11-11) yielded two runs over 5.1 innings.
The Yankees trailed 7-1 after five innings. Baltimore (81-81) took a first-inning lead on Matt Wieters’ two-run single and Gerardo Parra had a two-run single in a three-run fourth.
Chris Davis’ two-run homer in the fifth off Bryan Mitchell gave Baltimore a six-run lead and the Yanks’ gaze was soon fixed on the out-of-town scoreboard in right field.
Davis homered again in the eighth, his 47th of the season.
